title: 109_hr5612
content: The Act titled "Chattahoochee National Forest Act of 2006" establishes the Mountaintown National Scenic Area within the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area is established within the Chattahoochee National Forest in Georgia, consisting of approximately 13,382 acres. The Secretary of Agriculture will submit a final map and boundary description to Congress, with the same legal effect as if included in the Act. The Secretary of Agriculture will provide Congress with a final map and boundary description of the Mountaintown National Scenic Area in Georgia, which will be available for public inspection and have the same legal effect as if included in the Act. The map and boundary description of the Mountaintown National Scenic Area in Georgia will be available for public inspection in the Office of the Chief of the Forest Service. Any discrepancies between the acreage and the map will be resolved by the map and boundary description required by this subsection. The Secretary will manage the scenic area to ensure protection and preservation of its scenic and water quality. The Secretary will manage the Mountaintown National Scenic Area in Georgia to protect and preserve its scenic quality, water quality, natural characteristics, and water resources. Additionally, vegetation will be protected to provide wildlife and fish habitat, with a focus on developing old-growth forest characteristics within the area. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area in Georgia will be managed to protect its scenic and natural qualities, including water resources. Vegetation will be preserved to support wildlife and fish habitat, with a focus on developing old-growth forest characteristics. Recreation opportunities will also be provided in the area. Management purposes specified in the plan will take precedence over general laws and regulations for the National Forest System. The Mountaintown National Scenic Area in Georgia will be managed to protect its scenic and natural qualities, including water resources, vegetation, and wildlife habitat. Recreation opportunities will be provided, and a management plan will be developed within three years to conform to specified purposes. The Secretary will develop a management plan for the Mountaintown National Scenic Area within three years, as an amendment to the Chattahoochee National Forest's land and resource management plan. No new roads will be constructed within the scenic area. The Secretary will revise the land and resource management plan for the Chattahoochee National Forest to prohibit new road construction within the scenic area. Timber harvest is only allowed for fire, insect, and disease control, public safety, and trail maintenance. Vegetation management in the scenic area allows for timber harvest only for fire, insect, and disease control, public safety, and trail access. The Secretary may conduct vegetation manipulation for wildlife clearings and visual quality. Personal firewood harvesting is permitted along perimeter roads. Motorized travel is not allowed in the area. The Secretary may engage in vegetation manipulation for maintenance of wildlife clearings and visual quality. Firewood harvesting for personal use is allowed along perimeter roads. Motorized travel is generally not permitted in the scenic area, except for administrative use and wildlife management projects. Wildfires in the area will be suppressed. Within the scenic area, motorized travel may be authorized by the Secretary for administrative use and wildlife management projects. Wildfires will be suppressed in a manner consistent with management purposes, and insect and disease outbreaks may be controlled to maintain scenic quality and protect private lands. The scenic area is managed to control insect and disease outbreaks, maintain water quality, and withdraw federally owned lands from mining activities. The scenic area is managed to maintain or enhance water quality and federally owned lands are withdrawn from mining activities. SEC. 3. DESIGNATION OF ADDITIONAL NATIONAL FOREST SYSTEM LAND AS WILDERNESS IN GEORGIA. Designation of approximately 8,448 acres in Georgia as wilderness under the Wilderness Act, adding three areas to the Southern Nantahala Wilderness. Designation of new wilderness areas in Chattahoochee National Forest: Ben Gap, Shoal Branch, Tate Branch, Cedar Mountain, Duck Branch, and Wilson Cove. The Chattahoochee National Forest has designated several new wilderness areas, including Ben Gap, Shoal Branch, Tate Branch, Cedar Mountain, Duck Branch, Wilson Cove, Ellicott Rock Addition, Foster Branch, Ken Mountain, and Raven Cliffs. These additions range in size from 165 to 1,085 acres. The Chattahoochee National Forest has designated new wilderness areas, including Ellicott Rock Addition, Foster Branch, Ken Mountain, Raven Cliffs, Helton Creek, and Tripp Branch, ranging in size from 165 to 2,451 acres. The Secretary will submit maps and legal descriptions after the enactment of this Act. The Chattahoochee National Forest has designated new wilderness areas: Helton Creek (2,451 acres) in Raven Cliffs Wilderness and Tripp Branch (638 acres) in Tray Mountain Wilderness. The Secretary will provide final maps and boundary descriptions for these areas after the Act's enactment. The Congress will provide final maps and boundary descriptions for the newly designated wilderness areas in the Chattahoochee National Forest. The Secretary will administer these lands in accordance with the Wilderness Act and this section. The Congress will provide final maps and boundary descriptions for newly designated wilderness areas in the Chattahoochee National Forest. The Secretary will administer these lands in accordance with the Wilderness Act and this section, subject to valid existing rights. The effective date of the Wilderness Act for the designated wilderness lands will be the date of enactment of this Act. The Wilderness Act will be administered for newly designated wilderness areas in the Chattahoochee National Forest, with the effective date being the date of enactment of this Act. The State of Georgia's jurisdiction over fish and wildlife in the forest will not be affected by this section. The Federal land designated as wilderness in the Chattahoochee National Forest is withdrawn from all forms of entry, appropriation, or disposal under public land laws, and mining laws, subject to valid existing rights. Federal land designated as wilderness in Chattahoochee National Forest is withdrawn from entry, appropriation, or disposal under public land and mining laws, subject to valid existing rights.
